title: Why does no one want to live coach me?
body:
Every time a challenger player agrees to live coach to give me free wins, after stating the terms which I agree to, they then all of a sudden "don't feel like it".

It is almost like they cannot actually guarantee me these "free wins" I keep being told are so easily available.

I understand that they think I am the only one getting any benefit here, which is incorrect. But if that was the case, then wouldn't they have not agreed and then planned to do it in the first place?

I am only trying to either learn the game from a different perspective, or show how these games are not as free as they are claiming them to be. Where is the harm in that?

The only reason I can conceive is that they simply don't want to take the chance that they could be proven wrong and they know how badly their ego would be shattered.

Anyone else have any ideas?

replies.body:
Let me try this one then. It's generally accepted that the ranked system is a decent metric of skill, especially in the higher tiers yes? A Diamond ADC is going to be all around better than a Gold ADC, and a Challenger ADC is going to be all around better than that Diamond yes? This would indicate that rank has meaning, it's not just an arbitrary metric.

You believe yourself to be on par with Challenger players, yet are in Silver yourself so why is that? The most likely conclusion is that those Challengers players are all around better than you right? You might say teammates are the issue, but they are only 1/5 their team same as you, so what are they doing differently?

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=0005,timestamp=2018-02-08T09:08:28.475+0000)
> Let me try this one then. It's generally accepted that the ranked system is a decent metric of skill, especially in the higher tiers yes? A Diamond ADC is going to be all around better than a Gold ADC, and a Challenger ADC is going to be all around better than that Diamond yes? This would indicate that rank has meaning, it's not just an arbitrary metric.

Rank is an average, not absolute, which means it is not reliable. It has holes that lead to false information clearly defined in the equation. You cannot rely on the information you can only hope that it is right. Teams try to get players of a particular minimum rank and refuse to trial anyone below that level because they think it is a waste of time, but they still trial players who potentially could not even be up to that level. This is where I have the problem. If you are going to trial anyone, then trial everyone because rank is too unreliable for a source of information.

> You believe yourself to be on par with Challenger players, yet are in Silver yourself so why is that? The most likely conclusion is that those Challengers players are all around better than you right? You might say teammates are the issue, but they are only 1/5 their team same as you, so what are they doing differently?

Good question, that is what I have been trying to find out with this live coaching. In starcraft you will never see a silver player shit on a master level player even if they were fucking around, let alone 5 of them. So you tell me what I am doing wrong if I can be the major determining factor in winning a game against a diamond/challenger team, but I can't beat a team of silver players 100% of the time (as I would do in starcraft 2), where is the logic in that line of thought?

I have the answer but no one wants to listen or even entertain the idea, I had the answer from the start because I didn't buy into the bullshit that everyone is caught up in.

>Rank is an average

Yes and believe it or not, you have played way over enough games for that average to be fairly accurate.

You have played 1000's of games, that means that variance becomes minimised.

If a challenger player played 1000's of games on an account, that account would be in high elo, regardless of any bad luck or anything like that.

> [{quoted}](name=JasonWazza,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=000500000001,timestamp=2018-02-08T12:47:11.824+0000)
>
> Yes and believe it or not, you have played way over enough games for that average to be fairly accurate.
> 
> You have played 1000's of games, that means that variance becomes minimised.
> 
> If a challenger player played 1000's of games on an account, that account would be in high elo, regardless of any bad luck or anything like that.

I am not sure you understand what chance means. Sample size doesn't negate outliers.

Chance and average aren't the same thing. Averages, even mean averages which are heavily affected by outliers only become more accurate the larger the sample size. A large enough sample size *will* negate that outlier.

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=00050000000100000000,timestamp=2018-02-09T05:26:18.175+0000)
>
> Chance and average aren't the same thing. Averages, even mean averages which are heavily affected by outliers only become more accurate the larger the sample size. A large enough sample size *will* negate that outlier.

An infinite number of games is required to get an accurate sample size.
Why does it have to be infinite?

So it's not "infinite"
For accurate
Infinite results just means 100% accurate
But you can reach an acceptable accuracy with less than that
But still, it requires a lot
Because for a group of 10 people, you need to have every single matchup combination
So for people A B C D E F G H I J
You would need the game A B C D E verse F G H I J
So for that ABCDE x FGHIJ, you would have each one, to the power of how many roles there are
So you would have 10^5 games
For just 10 people
Which is like... 10000 games
But like... There's thousands upon thousands of players
So then you have to calculate the crossover
Which is 1m ^ 5 for static matches
And then put that to the power of how many matchups get switched around
So, we'll start with the standard, if they all just stick to 10 matches and only switch one person
Then it creates twice as many scenarios
So with 1m people, it's 1m/10 games
so that's 100000 games
Switch one person, you get 200000 unique games
So, let's say you have to switch everyone, it's a total of 1m - 10 (from the first game)
That's how many unique games there are
Which is equal to 100000 x 999990
Then you have to apply the role multiplier
So that's (100,000 x 999,990)^5
9.999500009999900000499999e+54
To get one person's rank, accurately, you would need every player to perform every combination, because the MMR system is a comparison system, not an individual performance system
But once someone plays ranked, they have to play all games
And... Let's see
Divide the total games by the amount of playersmeans...
Each player only needs to play 9.999500009999900000499999e+48 games
The infinite games accuracy is just repetition for validity
Because in those games you have disconnects, afks, etc
random stuff you can't help

I think your biggest problem is your looking for absolutes where they are irrelevant/impossible/misleading.

There's no one strategy that will win you every game, because every game is unique. What that means is that success in this game is not only judged on mechanics and knowledge, but adaptability. 

The degree to which you can adapt to your team comp, to your lane partner's playstyle, to the enemy playstyle, the enemy comp, the enemies strengths and weaknesses, your own strengths and weaknesses is very much going to limit or augment your ability to play effectively and therefore climb.

The better you adapt, the better you'll play, the faster you'll improve, and the faster you'll climb. From all your posts and the games I've looked at. That to me is the big thing you're missing. Your items, your wards, your roster, your mindset. Everything tells me you are looking for a black and white answer, and absolute, in a game of greys.
See, we give you the math and you say it is wrong.

You read a post, and instead of considering it for what it is, take it as an attack on your opinion and ignore it entirely.

Let's say you've played every champion into every possible matchup against every possible player. How does that help you? 

It doesn't. Doing something once doesn't help you. Math will not help you in game. Not unless you're secretly a super computer and can calculate exactly how much damage you're going to do and have done to you at any given moment.

Game knowledge will only help you so far in game. You need tactics, strategy, adaptability and mechanics. Even then, it's all well and good knowing what you need to do if you can't execute it because you aren't precise enough with your mouse, or fast enough with your reaction time. And that's completely ignoring player psychology.

There are no absolutes here that apply properly and none that will help you.

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=00050000000100000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-02-09T10:26:40.978+0000)
>
> You read a post, and instead of considering it for what it is, take it as an attack on your opinion and ignore it entirely.

>I think your biggest problem is your looking for absolutes where they are irrelevant/impossible/misleading.

I don't think you understand how this conversation is meant to proceed logically.

I gave you maths, and then you gave me an opinion with no evidence as to why I should accept what you are saying, instead of confronting what I have just given you.

These are the most direct paths to reaching a conclusion from this point:

1. Oh, that makes sense. I can see now exactly what you mean. (realisation)

2. I do not understand that math. (admitting lack of comprehension)

3. I can point out exactly where the errors are in your math, like so. (contesting the math)

Anything else you say is just bypassing a confrontation, if you do not wish to choose any of these options, you have nothing left in this discussion to provide.

I am only here to give people the chance the see the logic and maths behind what they are using, in hopes to create a better platform for an enhanced gaming experience. To me, games are simply tests designed to gauge our ability to achieve results, increase our understanding and broaden our abilities to perform in every day life. If the test is flawed in its system that is designed to achieve a goal, it is not achieving its goal. Then this is all purely for entertainment and drama, just an exercise in futility.

Or 4. I don't believe the equation has any relevance to what you are trying to achieve (higher rank/improvement).

Games are entertainment. There is entertainment in competition, but ultimately games are designed to be fun. To be an escape from the harsh reality. If you're not enjoying your time playing on some level, *then* it's an exercise in futility.

I tried, again, for some reason to help you, and you still either dodged or refused every advice I gave you, so I'm tapping out here. It's not worth the time.

Dismissing evidence? Who do you honestly think you are? You are clearly the one trying to advance your beliefs. You would clearly rather win an argument on the internet than actually get a higher elo.

Any high elo player will tell you your mindset is so horrible for ranked and I can see exactly why no one wants to coach you. 

You are pretentious and think you know a lot about maths and statistics but really you are forgetting a simple thing called common sense.

If you can't get to a higher elo, you must need to improve. Do you honestly think that with a 37% win rate in Silver 4 that you playing infinite games would get you your true elo which I'm assuming you think is much higher? 

The truth is that your frame of mind is delusional and you simply do not want to get a higher elo, I don't know what else to tell you.

I have read this whole discussion and none of what you are saying makes an ounce of sense.

The only thing logical you have said is that over an infinite number of games you would get a perfectly accurate elo. This is of course completely irrelevant considering ranked is a ladder and if you can't climb, you aren't good enough to climb.

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=0005000000010000000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-02-09T13:01:11.285+0000)
>
> Or 4. I don't believe the equation has any relevance to what you are trying to achieve (higher rank/improvement).
> 
> Games are entertainment. There is entertainment in competition, but ultimately games are designed to be fun. To be an escape from the harsh reality. If you're not enjoying your time playing on some level, *then* it's an exercise in futility.
> 
> I tried, again, for some reason to help you, and you still either dodged or refused every advice I gave you, so I'm tapping out here. It's not worth the time.

You tried helping me your own way, once again ending in the same outcome. You are basically telling me to jump off a bridge blind folded and have faith that I won't die on impact, instead of give me knowledge that it is safe because of a soft landing setup.

I am not a child, you will not get through to me by dismissing evidence. I want you to either falsify my evidence, or accept it.

So far you have told me that you have no idea what is going on in my games and you are claiming to be trying to help me in game.

Ever considered live coaching me to test to see if you can even give me free wins like everyone claims? Validate your own beliefs perhaps?

Regardless of whether or not you do anything to help me or not you can be confident that you are in the right, and you can use this as a point in any further discussions you have with people regarding the same situation.

Do you have a link to the match history for this game where you were the determining factor? Remember that you have to take your team into account as well. If the enemy is diamonds and a challenger or two, what was your team? Just having a good kda doesn't make you the determining factor.

No, it happened several years ago, I did not think I would have to reference it.

I was trialing for a gold team and they were doing placements, they had won 4 placements so we got put up against diamonds and a challenger.

I recall the enemy mid was a tf, the enemy adc was sivir, my support was a nautilius who was playing super passive, the enemy jungler was elise and was the challenger. I played twitch and at one point at mid game i was 16-3. My team had almost no deaths in their lanes as they were playing passively so I snowballed and my team tried to protect me although they did a pretty poor job but it was enough to win us teamfights and stop the enemy tf from assassinating me in the backline, because my build was designed for maximum exponential effectiveness my lifesteal did the rest to keep me alive and we were able to take control of the game and secure a win from it. The manager of the team was a female and I didn't make the team because I "didn't have good synergy with the support."

The enemy sivir was diamond 5 and the rest were around diamond something except for the challenger elise, I am pretty sure master wasn't even a tier back then.

The reason I was able to do my job so well was because my team wasn't feeding the shit out of the enemy, and then they did their best to try protect me when i was the key to winning. Something I never have from my teammates in solo queue. it wasn't a solo effort, nothing ever is no matter who is playing.

Well then you'll have to forgive those who aren't going to use solely your memory as evidence of a claim.

Rank is an average yes. The thing about averages is that the larger the sample size the more accurate that average is. For someone who has only played 50 games of ranked, winrate and rank can certainly be fairly meaningless. Generally you'd want at least 200 games before you'd consider it fairly accurate.

Looking through your match history, there are two things that immediately jump out to me. I know you're going to disagree on builds so I'll skip that one for now. What I'm looking at is your vision score. Which frankly even for silver is abysmal. 

Nobody expects you to be even with the support on vision score, but over your last 10 ADC games, the most wards you placed in  single game was 10, but your averages were 3 (median) and 4.7 (mean), and not a single control ward. That's only 6-8 minutes of vision in one location, in 20+ minute games.

Top is even worse with 3 (median) and 4 (mean). So my question is why?

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=00050000000000000000,timestamp=2018-02-08T13:27:59.138+0000)
>
> Top is even worse with 3 (median) and 4 (mean).

I was under advisement of a challenger player.

Also as an ADC I may require my trinket wards to reveal bushes in combat situations, as I am limited to 2 wards at most and there are 2 bushes in the lanes in bot, it is a good idea to keep my wards for those bushes and not engage unless I can account for the whole enemy team.
You were under the advisement of a Challenger player to not ward?

I was not told to ward the side bushes while split pushing, and since there is more than 2 areas I would need warded to guarantee vision, I was instead instructed to back out whenever the enemy wasn't pressuring anywhere else on the map.

Ok so while you're split pushing that's true, if you don't have eyes on the enemy, you shouldn't be there/assume they're coming for you. But what about the rest of the game? You're telling me you only used 3 wards to protect you in lane AND In fights AND for TPs AND for Baron control?

No the entire strategy was split push with yorick, meaning when the enemy is taking an objective or threatening one, I am on the other side of the map threatening towers. So I straight up never group for any control over any objectives. I was just a backdoor threat.

I avoid any fights that are not 1v1 and there is no need to put wards down for tp when you have minions to tp on. The wards are specifically for laning phase.

Also my team tilts and flames me for buying control wards as an ADC, so maybe riot should be educating people about their own game rather than feeding them bullshit.

Even if you were splitpushing all game, you have free wards. I understand not wanting to use them top if you have eyes on the enemy and are going to be leaving soon to join a fight or something, but why not put one on baron on your way past? Enemy Tri? Behind their tower? Put one down in lane so you can recall and TP back? And why take TP if you're not going to use it? If you're going to ignore your team and push all game why not take ignite or heal for better 1v1s?

And you team tilting/flaming for you buying red wards? I find that hard to believe, and even if they did, that's on them. You say you belong a lot higher than them, so why would you take their word for it? And still you's only using 3-4 wards a game as ADC. 3-4 **free** wards.

> [{quoted}](name=Seras Dragon,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=00050000000000000000000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-02-09T05:24:57.587+0000)
>
> Even if you were splitpushing all game, you have free wards. I understand not wanting to use them top if you have eyes on the enemy and are going to be leaving soon to join a fight or something, but why not put one on baron on your way past? Enemy Tri? Behind their tower? Put one down in lane so you can recall and TP back? And why take TP if you're not going to use it? If you're going to ignore your team and push all game why not take ignite or heal for better 1v1s?
> 
> And you team tilting/flaming for you buying red wards? I find that hard to believe, and even if they did, that's on them. You say you belong a lot higher than them, so why would you take their word for it? And still you's only using 3-4 wards a game as ADC. 3-4 **free** wards.

Okay you don't actually know the strategy behind split pushing so you can't really make any suggestions on a scenario you don't know of.

So are you telling me I shouldn't be concerned about my team tilting and playing like shit because they are too distracted by what I am doing to play properly? So you are telling me I should be playing optimally even though it leads to losses because my team is tilting and losing all their lanes and then those lanes come down to me and force me out of the game? Reason because it is their problem and not mine?

You're right, I'm not a top laner and never have been, so what about someone who is:

> Not ever joining fights used to work back when split pushers were big, but now unless your team is stupid ahead they're just going to get dumpstered while you're messing around elsewhere. 4 or 5 enemies is going to push a lot harder than 1 top laner.

> If you're versing a dive comp your team will just lose if you aren't with them. If your team has strong defensive then split pushing can be strong, it can get you objectives while they're stuck trying to siege, but at that point any smart team is just going to match you. You have to read the game, you can't expect to just do one thing all game and win.

Frankly I think people tilting and flaming you over buying a control ward is a blatant over exaggeration. I'd believe it happening once, or happening because you bought a red ward and a long sword instead of your BF, but no sane person is going to be mad about having vision, it would be the opposite.
I would coach you, but from your posts, you have no desire to actually improve.

no you wouldn't coach me, that is all you have to say.

Don't try to claim that you would if you are not going to that is the entire reason I made this post.

I mean he is right, you don't want a coach, you just want someone to tell you, that you are right.

Coaches are going to actually help you improve, if you let them, but you've made it clear that you won't let them.

People are allowed to change their minds. From coaching experience, some players are just not worth the effort to be coached, because they come in with all kinds of preconceived nonsense. No amount of coaching changes their mind. And essentially its not really coaching, just finding a sparring partner to prattle off some ideas.
That being said, if you pay someone the right amount of money for their time, they might spend some time with you!
If I was rich enough to pay people money to attempt to teach them things, then I would have just bought a challenger account.
Well I mean, people's time is valuable, you don't get coaching in other realms for free. Try lol-coaching you might find someone on there that offers free or very cheap coaching.

I tried free high level coaching before but they just analysed a replay, didn't help at all.

No one's time is more valuable than anyone else's.
A one game sample size is not great for working out common weaknesses of a player, but you should have been able to take something away from the replay analysis?
People want challenger players to coach them. That means theirs a demand, which means they can charge for that time. In terms of league their time is quite literally more valuable than yours.

>I am only trying to either learn the game from a different perspective

Then you have to play the game from a different perspective, instead of simply dismissing the opinion or half assing an attempt at playing it. One cynical game won't teach you much at all. If you want to learn another perspective, you have to accept it as it is, and try it properly before saying you don't like it or it's wrong.

Incorrect, according to everyone, I am missing something, not dismissing something.

"it is the mark of an educated mind to entertain an idea, without accepting it."

Funny thing is that I am entertaining the idea of teammates not affecting your rank just by trying to solo carry which I have been attempting for many years using all different strategies, but people are not entertaining the idea that they do affect your rank.

Everyone seems eager to make claims, without any real evidence to back it up. The worst part is they are not willing to prove it.

Also, you didn't actually answer my question, you just stated what you thought I conclude with. Which is funny because I never conclude anything. My mind has been changed many times by experience and research and I am not even considering the possibility that there is nothing more than what I have perceived. The very fact that I am human means I am prone to making a ton of mistakes. The biggest difference I see is that I am more openly willing to admit that I could be making mistakes. Which is also the reason I am so eager to be proven wrong, because I know that I am so open to being proven wrong and I am just begging to be shown what I am missing. I am told that 95% of my games are winnable and as that is a win rate that is alien to me, I would very much like to explore it, but no one is willing to show me and I can find no evidence anywhere to support anything close to it. So based on my experience dealing with humans, I can only thus far conclude that they are talking out of their ass.
And that is exactly why no one want's to play with you.
why? he had many points in there and you haven't said which one is the reason.
Holy shit I’ve never seen that interview before. What a train wreck

Yeah. I mean I’ve experienced him before but that was a whole new level. 

And some of those other posts holy moly.
That's why you will find, that no one on boards takes anything he says as anything serious.
I don’t think anyone that’s talked to him for longer than 5 minutes will take him seriously.

Yeah this appears to be a religion for you guys. Not only does the system disprove it's own function, but even when brought detailed proof you still have 100% complete faith in your religion and will not even consider the possibility that it could be wrong. So of course you are not going to take me seriously, you don't even have the ability to perceive yourself as being in the wrong.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D5e0ySIJwW4

Denying reality straight up just makes you a danger to society because you are capable of literally anything without objective reasoning.

Have you ever considered flipping that around?

Yeah this appears to be a religion for you. Even when brought detailed proof you still have 100% complete faith in your religion and will not even consider the possibility that it could be wrong. So of course you are not going to take anyone else seriously, you don't even have the ability to perceive yourself as being in the wrong.

If your first response to every post trying to help you is "incorrect" instead of, "I'll try and see where you're coming from", you're not going to get anywhere fast.

How do you feel about the guy in that video who is denying reality, telling you that you are the one denying reality.

This is a simple argument that has basic logical principles.

You can't logically claim anything you say is always right and that I am not allowed to consider it wrong once I have read and understood the text you have provided on this thread. If you did not put forward what you were trying to say correctly in the first place, then take the time to correct the statements and convey your message correctly.

If you want to help me, perhaps try to help me my way, since none of the other ways have succeeded. I know what will change my mind, so why not work with that?

>This is a simple argument that has basic logical principles.

Ok here is simple Logic.

The ranked system works, and you simply just can't climb because your not good at the game, yet continue to believe that you are better then everyone.

However, there are always tons of streamers that by themselves do "unranked to challenger" climbs all the time.

So if you are better then these players, why can't you do that?

That’s not how the ranking system works. 

Also 

> [{quoted}](name=Transcender,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=EmP1i2Kq,comment-id=00000000000000000001000100000000000000000000000000000006,timestamp=2018-02-09T01:55:04.033+0000)
>
> https://imgur.com/a/yRKDJ
> 
> The mathematics of the system being used should be self explanatory in disproving itself

Makes no sense
